application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The transmission of a graph or digraph G is the sum of all distances in G. StFict bounds on the transmission are collected and extended for several classes of graphs and digraphs. For example, in the class of 2connected or Z-edge-mnnected graphs of order n, the maximal transmission is realized only by the cycle C,. The independence of the transmission on the diameter or radius is shown. Remarks are also given about the NP-hardness of some related algorithmic problems.

div.head: SOME RELATED NP-HARD PROBLEMS
div.p: In this section we mention some algorithmic problems related to the transmission. In [23] Johnson, Lenstra, and Rinnooy Kan considered the following problem.

Network Design Problem. Consider a graph G in which every edge e has assigned a length a(e) and a cost c(e). The transmission of a factor F of G is generalized as expected and the cost of F is defined as the sum of its edge costs. Further, a number b (budget) is prescribed. The problem is to design a factor F of G which minimizes the transmission under the constraint that the cost of F does not exceed b.

Unfortunately, this important problem is NP-hard, as shown by Johnson et al. 1231, even in the simple case in which all a(e) = c(e) = 1 and b = n -1; i.e., the budget restricts the choice to spanning trees of G.

Nevertheless, if G is a complete graph and all a(e) = c(e) = 1, then the answer is easy. Indeed, by Theorem l(a) we can take for F any factor of G with b edges and with diam(F) s 2 (this is possible whenever

div.p: The network design problem for digraphs (equally defined) is also NPhard, even in the simple case in which all a(e) = c(e) = 1 and b = n . That is, the problem is equivalent to the NP-hard problem of finding a Hamiltonian cycle of the digraph G (see, e.g., [181).
